Comment: ***From Rolling Stone’s Peter Wade:***  Sen. Cory Booker and House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries are holding a livestreamed sit-in on the Capitol steps in protest of a forthcoming Republican budget they say will gut Medicaid — a federal and state program that helps to cover medical costs for people with limited income as well as disabled children and adults.  The sit-in began at sunrise, shortly after 6 a.m., and Booker and Jeffries promised to stay for “a good number of hours.”  Read more: [https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/politics-news/booker-jeffries-capitol-sit-in-medicaid-1235326047/](https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/politics-news/booker-jeffries-capitol-sit-in-medicaid-1235326047/)

Comment: This would actually mean something if they did a sit-in on a week day where it stood the changes of actually disrupting something. It would have a greater impact if they actually organized people and brought hundreds or even thousands to the sit-in.  This is no different from a politician livestreaming from home and bringing on a few guests throughout the stream. My prediction is that they'll be out there for the day, collect the political points they think they need to stay in office, and then go home to pat themselves on the back for al their hard work defending America.  I'm glad to see them do something, but this isn't nearly enough nor effective enough. Real action is what AOC and Bernie are doing by holding rallies and town halls. It's drafting legislation, it's building and communicating a plan and a vision. What's the Dems' plan? I certainly haven't seen it, aside from James Carville's suggestion to roll over and play dead. A strategy effectively modeled  by Chuck Schumer.
